column1: When Elsa awoke the next morning in her silken bed
column3: she saw a beautiful dress lying over the back of a chair
column4: ready for her to put on. A maid came in to comb out her long hair
column5: and brought the finest linen for her use; but nothing gave Elsa so much joy as the little pair of embroidered shoes that she held in her hand
column6: for the girl had hitherto been forced to run about barefoot by her cruel stepmother. In her excitement
column7: she never gave a thought to the rough clothes she had worn the day before
column8: which had disappeared as if by magic during the night. Who could have taken them? Well
column9: she was to know that by-and-by. But we can guess that the doll had been dressed in them
column10: which was to go back to the village in her stead. By the time the sun rose
column11: the doll had attained her full size
column12: and no one could have told one girl from the other. Elsa started back when she met herself as she looked only yesterday.
